[The musician]106-the musician , perhaps , had no effectual means of suggesting [their]113-his own chosen disciples departure ; but neither was [their]113-his own chosen disciples homage , being very womanly and obvious , unpleasing to [him]106-the musician ; and when [the well - dressed Philistines]116-the well - dressed philistines had driven away in [their]116-the well - dressed philistines carriages , [he]106-the musician abandoned the attitude of [the debonair host]117-the debonair host and took up that of [the prophet]118-the prophet instead , which at once gave a serious turn to the conversation . [He]106-the musician then propounded [his]106-the musician own theories , or [somebody else]119-somebody else 's , at great length , and [the chorus]120-the chorus assented with a gentle murmur of approbation whenever there was a pause . [Squire Raleigh]39-squire raleigh was [a philanthropist]182-a philanthropist . But philanthropy in [town]183-town is a costly amusement , and [Squire Raleigh]39-squire raleigh had [a large family]184-a large family , whose claims could not comfortably be ignored in favor of [charitable institutions]185-charitable institutions , although [a philanthropist with a love for mankind]186-a philanthropist with a love for mankind can not be expected to do as much for [[his]186-a philanthropist with a love for mankind own children]187-his own children as [an ordinary domesticated egoist]188-an ordinary domesticated egoist . Nevertheless , after the endowment of [an orphan asylum]189-an orphan asylum , and the failure of a Liberal newspaper speculation , and the gift of [a public park]190-a public park to [the people]1051-the people had been followed by the reduction of [his]39-squire raleigh income to one - third of its original value , [the vigorous reformer]192-the vigorous reformer yielded to the persuasions of [[his]39-squire raleigh sons]193-his sons and [[his]39-squire raleigh lawyers]194-his lawyers and retired to [[his]39-squire raleigh country estate]195-his country estate , with a knighthood , a troublesome liver , and a firm resolve to get to the bottom of the land question . At [Murville Manor]3-murville manor , [an old Georgian house standing near [a quaint little village]197-a quaint little village in [one of]198-one of [the home counties]199-the home counties]196-an old georgian house standing near a quaint little village in one of the home counties , [Sir Marcus Raleigh]40-sir marcus once more tried to forget the disagreeable facts of an income with decreasing resources and [a family of increasing claims]200-a family of increasing claims , and plunged into fresh philanthropic schemes , this time relating to small holdings , and the growth of potatoes for the million , and the advancement in general of [the agricultural laborer]201-the agricultural laborer . Such energy naturally brought [the enthusiast]202-the enthusiast into collision with [[his]39-squire raleigh own farming tenants]203-his own farming tenants , who liked to preserve the monopoly of grumbling to [themselves]203-his own farming tenants , and although not hesitating to complain of the difficulties of making [their]203-his own farming tenants land pay , yet objected strongly to having small portions of it wrested from [them]203-his own farming tenants and given to [[their]203-his own farming tenants own laborers]204-their own laborers instead , who throve upon [them]203-his own farming tenants straightway . It likewise bred strained relations between [the Squire]205-the squire and [the old rector , who in [his]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds own way of [Sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds]207-sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds , was [a philanthropist of an old world form]208-a philanthropist of an old world form , and could not understand why [the traditional supporter of church charities]209-the traditional supporter of church charities should prefer to invent charities of [his]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds own and allow [the church]210-the church to fall into debt meanwhile . [[His]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds family]211-his family also , who had not inherited philanthropic tendencies , failed to appreciate the unselfishness of [[their]211-his family father]212-their father in this direction , and complained with the grossest individualism of the want of pocket money . [They]211-his family complained , too , of being forced to exchange [a town]213-a town life , where [they]211-his family could at least sink [[their]211-his family father]212-their father 's personality in the oblivion of society , for [a country]215-a country one , where it was impossible to remain unknown for miles round , where philanthropy was cheap and therefore more rife than before , and where a large staff of [men - servants]216-men - servants was replaced by [a so - called handy man]217-a so - called handy man . [The handy man]218-the handy man , by the way , in spite of advertising [himself]218-the handy man in the county paper as competent to look after " pony , cart , [garden]1101-garden , boots , knives , fifteen shillings a week , Sundays , and beer , "[218-the handy man] had as yet shown no decided talent in any of these particulars , except in the last - mentioned one . Among a mass of other inconsistencies , which almost likened [him]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds to [a schoolboy who is having a romp through life instead of playing the game seriously]219-a schoolboy who is having a romp through life instead of playing the game seriously , [the Squire]205-the squire , while considering [[his]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds children]221-his children in the light of impedimenta , yet cherished a passionate affection for the least worthy of [them]221-his children all , for the one to whom nature had decreed that [he]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds should bequeath , with a liberality [he]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds had shown [[his]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds children]221-his children in no other respect , the largest share of [his]206-the old rector , who in his own way of sunday - schools , and coal clubs , and relief funds own failings . [Jack Raleigh]41-jack was handsome , fascinating , improvident to a degree , with no fixed code of morality and no definite powers of reasoning , ruling [himself]41-jack and [his]41-jack actions entirely by a kind of blind instinct such as [we]223-we find in healthy animals or in [children]224-children . [His]41-jack love , like [his]41-jack antipathy , was of an elementary character ; if [he]41-jack found [himself]41-jack in a complicated situation , which was not rare , [he]41-jack would merely choose the most pleasant course open to [him]41-jack , without giving it a moment 's consideration , and would follow it gayly until another obstacle arose which would have to be treated in a similar manner . Whether [he]41-jack was the happier for feeling nothing deeply , belongs to those questions which are argued by thousands of lives every day without a conclusive answer being found to them . That [his]41-jack temperament was the sunnier for it and that [his]41-jack misdeeds were less harmful , is most certain ; and since [the God whom [he]41-jack believed in , if [he]41-jack believed in one at all , was a kind of inexhaustible Being who could offer [him]41-jack as many fresh opportunities as [he]41-jack had squandered already , and seemed to be the cause , in some indirect way that [Jack]41-jack never attempted to fathom , of occasional magnificent music in [churches]226-churches and [cathedrals]227-cathedrals]225-the god whom he believed in , if he believed in one at all , was a kind of inexhaustible being who could offer him as many fresh opportunities as he had squandered already , and seemed to be the cause , in some indirect way that jack never attempted to fathom , of occasional magnificent music in churches and cathedrals , [his]41-jack religion as well as [his]41-jack excellent digestion saved [him]41-jack from the fits of depression that usually accompany the sanguine disposition . [He]41-jack had discovered before [he]41-jack was out of [his]41-jack teens that [England]4-england was not [the place for one so restless as [he]41-jack]228-the place for one so restless as he , and [he]41-jack had been sent out to more than one colony " to try [his]41-jack luck , "[205-the squire] as [the Squire]205-the squire said , in a vague hope of shifting [his]205-the squire uneasy responsibility for [[his]205-the squire son]230-his son 's actions on to fortune . But [fortune]42-fortune , although not philanthropic in [her]231-her tendencies , and having no nobler vocation to distract [her]231-her from [her]231-her plain duty of looking after [[her]231-her prodigal sons]232-her prodigal sons , refused to help [him]41-jack , and [he]41-jack inevitably returned [home]233-home with more debts , [more friends]234-more friends , more anecdotes , but no more stability than before . It was on a dull morning in July , at breakfast time , that [Jack]41-jack caused [[his]41-jack father]235-his father for the hundredth time to recognize [his]41-jack existence in an unpleasant manner . It was an unfortunate time for [his]41-jack letter to arrive , for there was a mist that day , and as [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus was profoundly ignorant both of meteorology and the crops , and pretended to be [an authority on both]236-an authority on both , [he]40-sir marcus chose to feel injured because [Helen]43-helen assured [him]40-sir marcus that it was not going to rain , and that [his]40-sir marcus hay was not going to be spoiled . To which [the Squire]205-the squire , who never could endure the plain truths of [[his]205-the squire eldest daughter]238-his eldest daughter , replied testily that the mist did mean rain , that [his]205-the squire hay was going to be spoiled as it always was , and that [he]205-the squire [himself]205-the squire was [a ruined man]239-a ruined man ; [he]205-the squire then sat down at the now silent table and sighed in a dejected manner . Presently , finding that [no one]153-no one was looking at [him]205-the squire , [he]205-the squire roused [himself]205-the squire partially , and made a hearty breakfast behind [his]205-the squire newspaper ; and when the conversation around [him]205-the squire was once more in full swing [he]205-the squire condescended to look at [his]205-the squire letters . [He]205-the squire opened [Jack]41-jack 's first , as [he]205-the squire always did . It was the old story , told in [the boy]241-the boy 's usual careless manner : [Canada]44-canada had grown too small for [him]241-the boy , [he]241-the boy was feeling homesick , and was about to sail for [England]4-england , and would be with [[his]241-the boy father]235-his father almost as soon as [his]205-the squire letter , to which effect [he]41-jack was [[his]235-his father loving son]243-his loving son [Jack]41-jack . It was not the first letter of the kind that [the Squire]205-the squire had received from the same source , and [he]205-the squire knew what this one meant : [Jack]41-jack would be back again before the week was out , with an accumulation of debts and not a dollar in [his]41-jack pocket , [Jack]41-jack , with [his]41-jack sunny smile , and [his]41-jack nonchalance , and [his]41-jack utter unconsciousness of offence . [Jack]41-jack meant money , [family]245-family meant money , and [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus was close upon overdrawing [his]40-sir marcus banking account already , and had promised a large subscription only the day before to [the building fund of [the village reading - room]247-the village reading - room]246-the building fund of the village reading - room . If there had been [no stranger present]248-no stranger present [he]205-the squire would have relieved [his]205-the squire feelings by a characteristic outburst ; but [Lady Joan]38-lady joan sat opposite to [him]205-the squire and saw as much as [she]38-lady joan wished to see without raising [her]38-lady joan eyes from [her]38-lady joan plate , and [he]205-the squire felt instinctively that [he]205-the squire might merely succeed in making [himself]205-the squire ridiculous if [he]205-the squire spoke before the opportunity occurred ; and , impetuous man as [he]205-the squire was , something [he]205-the squire could not define restrained [him]205-the squire from creating a situation just then which should not be dignified . So [he]205-the squire read the letter over again , and [he]205-the squire listened mechanically to the conversation of [[his]205-the squire offending children]249-his offending children , without heeding what [they]249-his offending children said . " After all , "[32-digby] [Digby]32-digby was saying , with a gravity which the subject hardly merited , for in the heart of [[his]32-digby own family]250-his own family , although [he]32-digby still remained [the prophet]118-the prophet , yet [he]32-digby refrained from provoking the serious discussions which were only fitting within the sacred walls of [the studio]252-the studio , " after all , it does not matter how bad [a fellow]1102-a fellow is , if [he]1102-a fellow is only artistically so , [I]32-digby mean if [he]1102-a fellow will only be thorough over it . "[32-digby] " It does not matter how wicked [we]1103-we all are , so long as [we]1103-we can see the humor of sin . To be able to laugh at [ourselves]1103-we is the great thing , "[38-lady joan] murmured [Lady Joan]38-lady joan . " There is nothing so depressing , "[106-the musician] continued [the musician]106-the musician , without heeding the interruption , " as the spectacle of [a man who will not face [his]1104-a man who will not face his own wickedness — or even his own goodness own wickedness — or even [his]1104-a man who will not face his own wickedness — or even his own goodness own goodness]1104-a man who will not face his own wickedness — or even his own goodness . It is a sign of the age , this wretched spirit of compromise ; [we]1103-we do n't live in [town]183-town because it is unhealthy , and the fogs are so bad — "[106-the musician] " [[My]45-lady raleigh dear]1106-my dear , that was not the reason , "[45-lady raleigh] [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh murmured — also unheeded . " — and [we]1103-we do n't live in [the country]1070-the country because it is too far to come up to the concerts ; so [we]1103-we live at [Crouch End]5-crouch end or [Putney]6-putney , where [an exasperating local railway]1108-an exasperating local railway lies between [us]1103-we and [St. James 's Hall]1-st. james 's hall , and where the ends of the fogs hang about for days . [We]1103-we have n't the pluck to say yea or nay ; [we]1103-we leave all [our]1103-we decisions to [the gods]1109-the gods , who throw them back upon [us]1103-we again , or to — to fate , who only plays with [us]1103-we at will ; [we]1103-we would do anything to shirk the responsibility of the ego . Look at [Helen]43-helen , now ; the bent of [her]43-helen character is towards religion , yet [she]43-helen hesitates to go into [a convent]1110-a convent . Therefore [her]43-helen religion does not make [her]43-helen picturesque . "[45-lady raleigh] " [Digby]32-digby ! How can [you]32-digby argue at breakfast time ? [She]43-helen had not recovered from [her]43-helen passage of arms with [the Squire]39-squire raleigh . [Digby]32-digby plodded on with [his]32-digby breakfast and [his]32-digby theory . " [We]1112-we are all the same , as [a family]1113-a family . It is an age of compromise ; [we]1112-we are [all cowards]1116-all cowards . "[32-digby] " [Digby]32-digby is so fond of taking [his]32-digby own particular failings and generalizing them , "[43-helen] said [the still ruffled]254-the still ruffled [Helen]43-helen to [nobody in particular]255-nobody in particular . " [People with decided opinions]1117-people with decided opinions , [picturesque people]1118-picturesque people , as [you]1119-you call [them]1118-picturesque people , are [people with fads]1120-people with fads ; and [I]38-lady joan hate [people with fads]1120-people with fads , "[38-lady joan] said [Lady Joan]38-lady joan , " [they]1120-people with fads are ten times more uninteresting than the weathercock sort of people who make compromises . And why do [you]1119-you want to be quarrelling with the age perpetually ? It seems a nice comfortable sort of age to [me]38-lady joan ; [I]38-lady joan suppose it has a different aspect for [musical people]1122-musical people . "[38-lady joan] [Digby]32-digby 's end of the table was always the most popular whenever [he]32-digby was at [home]233-home , which was not often enough to spoil [his]32-digby reputation,—more popular at all events than the other end , where [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh insisted on making the tea , and made it very badly , and where [the Squire]205-the squire opened [his]32-digby letters and found they were mostly bills . If [[his]32-digby eldest son]258-his eldest son had not been monopolizing the conversation on this morning in particular , the efforts of [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus to make a sensation by sighing deeply and rustling the letter in [his]32-digby hand might have succeeded in attracting some notice ; but as it was , [he]32-digby was quite unheeded , and [[his]32-digby wife]129-his wife went on spilling the milk behind the urn , and filling up the teapot with water which had boiled half an hour ago , while the noisy chatter was carried on uninterruptedly round [Digby]32-digby and [Lady Joan]38-lady joan . "[32-digby] Perhaps country life was more trying to [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh than to [any other member of [[her]45-lady raleigh family]262-her family]261-any other member of her family ; for , with the inconsequence of [woman]1067-woman , [she]45-lady raleigh could not forgive [[her]45-lady raleigh husband]264-her husband for selling [[their]265-we [London]8-london house]266-their london house , although [herself]45-lady raleigh [the first instigator of the scheme]267-the first instigator of the scheme . To remind [him]264-her husband continually of the fact that [the place]268-the place did not agree with [her]45-lady raleigh , [she]45-lady raleigh refused to trust [herself]45-lady raleigh to [the handy man]218-the handy man 's whip , and never walked further than [the garden]270-the garden gate , by which means [she]45-lady raleigh preserved [her]45-lady raleigh constitution admirably , and ruined [her]45-lady raleigh nervous system ; and in this unhealthy condition of mind [she]45-lady raleigh shut [herself]45-lady raleigh up in [Murville Manor]3-murville manor , where [her]45-lady raleigh sole occupations became the mismanagement of [[her]45-lady raleigh household]271-her household , and the perusal of the illustrated papers . "—The[205-the squire] [Squire]39-squire raleigh always found that [his]39-squire raleigh philanthropic sentiments did not sound nearly so effective in [[his]39-squire raleigh own home]273-his own home as when thundered forth from a rickety platform in [the village schoolroom]274-the village schoolroom ; [the family circle]275-the family circle is at all times [a great leveller]276-a great leveller , and [his]39-squire raleigh constant terror of the ridiculous brought [him]39-squire raleigh swiftly back to the present actual grievance : " Do [you]45-lady raleigh ask [me]39-squire raleigh why , when [I]39-squire raleigh receive a letter like this from [the son [I]39-squire raleigh have loved and educated and denied [myself]39-squire raleigh for]1133-the son i have loved and educated and denied myself for ? " [He]41-jack does not say [he]41-jack is in debt , "[45-lady raleigh] said [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh , through a mist of joyful tears . [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus twisted [his]40-sir marcus napkin into a tangle and threw it on the floor . " Say ? "[40-sir marcus] [he]40-sir marcus cried , striding towards the door ; " do n't [I]40-sir marcus know what [he]41-jack means , [the rascal]1136-the rascal ? [I]40-sir marcus tell [you]1137-you [I]40-sir marcus 've done with [him]41-jack for once and for always ; [he]41-jack shall enter [[my]40-sir marcus house]1138-my house no more ; and if [he]41-jack comes [here]1084-here with [his]41-jack intolerable impudence , [I]40-sir marcus shall show [him]41-jack the door . It is right that [I]40-sir marcus should make an example of [him]41-jack , whatever it costs [me]40-sir marcus to do it ; and though [he]41-jack is [[my]40-sir marcus own son]1140-my own son [I]40-sir marcus will harden [my]40-sir marcus heart and do it . "[40-sir marcus] And with a sense almost of relief at having found a justifiable reason for avoiding this fresh trouble , and moreover a lurking suspicion that any such reason was wholly ineffectual to prevent [Jack]41-jack from coming [home]233-home , [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus flung [himself]40-sir marcus out of [the room]135-the room and banged the door . " [Jack]41-jack ought to be ashamed of [himself]41-jack ; how can [he]41-jack expect [papa]1144-papa to do any more for [him]41-jack ? "[43-helen] said [the implacable Helen]43-helen . [Dear Lady Joan]48-lady joan , [you]48-lady joan must pay no heed to what [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus said just now ; [he]40-sir marcus does not mean all [he]40-sir marcus says , [you]48-lady joan know , and [he]40-sir marcus was just a little startled by the suddenness of dear [Jack]41-jack 's decision ; it is [[my]283-her mother husband]1147-my husband 's way of hiding [his]40-sir marcus real emotion . [I]283-her mother 'm sure [I]283-her mother do n't know why [he]40-sir marcus should make so much fuss over a trifle when [we]1148-we have so many real troubles to bear.—Now , [[my]283-her mother dear]1106-my dear [Digby]32-digby , [you]32-digby know [I]283-her mother do not allow smoking in [the dining - room]1150-the dining - room ; how can [you]32-digby be so unkind as to add wilfully to all [my]283-her mother worries ? [I]283-her mother shall have a headache for certain , now.—Tom , [darling]1151-darling , open the window , and try to get the horrid smell out ; [I]283-her mother feel distracted ! "[32-digby] observed [Digby]32-digby , holding the offending cigarette out of the window , and trying to hide by a supreme indifference [his]32-digby consciousness at that moment that [a prophet]148-a prophet is without honor in [[his]148-a prophet own country]285-his own country . [Lady Joan]48-lady joan , from a studied attitude on the wide old window seat , was not in the least deceived by [his]32-digby manner , and laughed clearly and mockingly . " Oh , [the dear boy]1145-the dear boy , "[45-lady raleigh] said [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh , in a restored and cheerful tone , " to think that [he]41-jack may come at any moment , and there is no ale in [the house]1155-the house . [Helen]43-helen , [you]43-helen must write at once , and , dear [me]45-lady raleigh ! [we]1156-we must watch for every footstep all day ; and there are the sheets too,—where is [Nurse]1157-nurse ? [Dear Lady Joan]48-lady joan , [you]43-helen must forgive the emotions of [a foolish old mother]1158-a foolish old mother ; [I]45-lady raleigh assure [you]43-helen [I]45-lady raleigh am never flurried like this ; but even the best of [housekeepers]1159-housekeepers would be disturbed by such a sudden event . And [he]41-jack really must not have damp sheets ; [he]41-jack has slept in a blanket for two years , [he]41-jack tells [me]45-lady raleigh , and damp sheets are so dangerous ; but [he]41-jack shall have them to - night , bless [him]41-jack ! Oh , [children]224-children ! look , look ! who is that coming along behind the hedge ? Move out of the way , [Digby]32-digby , and do n't make so much noise , [everybody]166-everybody . "[45-lady raleigh] A moment 's breathless silence was followed by a shout of laughter as the unmistakable corduroys of [the handy man]218-the handy man came into view . " [George]49-george , [George]49-george , come here , "[45-lady raleigh] exclaimed [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh ; " [you]49-george must not leave [this spot]1163-this spot all day long , as [Master Jack]50-jack may be here at any minute . Do [you]49-george understand ? But do n't go beyond [the grounds]1167-the grounds , whatever [you]49-george do . [Dear boy]1168-dear boy , how [I]45-lady raleigh love [him]50-jack ! " Not [he]50-jack ! That is not [Jack]50-jack 's way either . [He]50-jack will drive up in [a coach]1170-a coach and four when [we]1171-we have given up expecting [him]50-jack , and want to know why [we]1171-we did not all go down to [the station]1165-the station in a body to meet [him]50-jack . " Only until [he]50-jack begins to say why [he]50-jack has come , and the rain has spoiled the hay , "[32-digby] [he]32-digby said , with another laugh . " Interested in duck - breeding , did [you]48-lady joan say ? " [I]45-lady raleigh can hear wheels , "[45-lady raleigh] said [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh , suddenly . "[32-digby] And finding that mercenary argument did not produce the effect [he]32-digby wanted , [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus fled from the sound of voices coming dangerously near , and beat a sheepish retreat into [[his]40-sir marcus library]328-his library on the opposite side of [the hall]173-the hall . " It is curious , "[32-digby] said [Digby]32-digby , in [his]32-digby oratorical way , " how [the father]1114-the father can forgive anything but want of solid success . [He]1114-the father does n't care a hang that [Jack]50-jack has been [the most popular fellow in [the colony]1212-the colony]1211-the most popular fellow in the colony , but if [he]1114-the father had made [his]1114-the father pile and had something to show for [his]1114-the father popularity , then [he]1114-the father would proclaim it on [the housetops]1213-the housetops . What a curious age it is , and how [we]331-they love to judge by results ! By the way , [Jack]50-jack will have a warm time if [the father]1114-the father keeps it up , wo n't [he]1114-the father ? "[32-digby] Even [the prophet]118-the prophet has to drop into the colloquial sometimes . [Pack of [women]1228-women and [children]224-children]1227-pack of women and children , with no sense of the responsibilities of life ! — "[40-sir marcus] the columns began to vanish into mist , and [the hall]173-the hall seemed filled with one shout of laughter ; [the Squire]205-the squire gasped and recovered himself—"It 's [my]205-the squire duty as [a father]1141-a father to withhold [my]205-the squire forgiveness ; what else is [a poor man]1130-a poor man to do when [he]1130-a poor man has such [an enormous family]1232-an enormous family ? "[205-the squire] [The Squire]205-the squire 's voice had sunk into a whisper , and the " Daily Liberal "[205-the squire] shook like a leaf in the breeze . " And [the dear old guv]1238-the dear old guv , where is [he]1130-a poor man ? Why does n't [he]1130-a poor man come out as [he]1130-a poor man always does ? "[205-the squire] " [I]205-the squire tell [you]205-the squire this is [[my]205-the squire room]1241-my room ; it is n't much that belongs to [me]205-the squire , except [five sons]1242-five sons doing nothing , and [six unmarried daughters]1243-six unmarried daughters , but — but [this room]1244-this room is [[my]205-the squire property]1245-my property , and [I]205-the squire wo n't have [any one]1152-any one in , [I]205-the squire tell [you]205-the squire — what [a fool]1247-a fool [I]205-the squire was not to lock the door — eh , what ? who 's that , eh ? Damn the looking - glass ! "[205-the squire] There was a mirror over the fireplace , and the fireplace was opposite the door . It was too much for [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus ; if [the boy]241-the boy had shown the least sign of shame , of nervousness at meeting [him]40-sir marcus , it would have been easier to keep up a semblance of anger ; but , as usual , [Jack]50-jack 's bluntness of vision saved [him]40-sir marcus where finer instincts would have been [his]40-sir marcus ruin . "[338-the premier] [The premier]338-the premier 's speech on fruit - growing for the million fluttered down into the coal scuttle ; and [the Squire]205-the squire wiped [his]205-the squire spectacles violently , and gave in to the fascination of [the single man who never worked]345-the single man who never worked . And when [Digby]32-digby strolled in ten minutes later , [he]32-digby found [the prodigal]287-the prodigal filling [[his]287-the prodigal father]235-his father 's pipe with Canadian tobacco , and telling [him]287-the prodigal American anecdotes , while [the little room]348-the little room resounded with [their]349-their laughter . " Come in , [Digby]32-digby , and listen to [this fellow]1251-this fellow , "[40-sir marcus] said [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus , jovially ; " did [you]32-digby ever know such [a fellow]1102-a fellow as [Jack]50-jack ? It 's a pity [you]32-digby do n't try [America]13-america , [Digby]32-digby , it would do [you]32-digby a world of good , [man]1066-man ! "[40-sir marcus] [Digby]32-digby accepted the situation and [his]32-digby eviction with a laugh , not only because , as [he]32-digby had said to [Lady Joan]48-lady joan , [he]32-digby knew [he]32-digby would be received back into favor again on the morrow when the fascination of the prodigal would have exhausted itself for the time , but also from a lurking hope that [he]32-digby would at last have some chance of talking to [[their]349-their fair guest]350-their fair guest , whom [the Squire]205-the squire had as yet entirely monopolized , in the way [he]205-the squire usually monopolized [any stranger who would lend a willing and fresh ear to [his]205-the squire hobbies]352-any stranger who would lend a willing and fresh ear to his hobbies . But [the musician]106-the musician did not get [his]106-the musician chance that evening , though [he]106-the musician tried very hard for it . [Jack]50-jack 's return proved but a doubtful assistance to [him]32-digby : to begin with , it caused an alteration in the dinner - table , by which [he]32-digby found [himself]32-digby out of the range of [her]48-lady joan conversation ; it also made the conversation in [the drawing - room]296-the drawing - room afterwards more hopelessly general than ever , for [they]349-their all sat round in a circle and listened to the American anecdotes , and when the American anecdotes flagged for a moment [Digby]32-digby had to go to the piano and play [the returned wanderer]355-the returned wanderer 's favorite airs , while [the hero]356-the hero [himself]356-the hero took the opportunity of opening a desperate flirtation with [Lady Joan]48-lady joan under cover of the crashing chords of [[his]356-the hero eldest brother]357-his eldest brother . [The musician]106-the musician was full thirty years old , and had been in love almost as many times as [he]32-digby had photos in [[his]32-digby West End studio]359-his west end studio ; like [[his]32-digby father]235-his father , it was only the trifling circumstances of life , or its visions , that seemed to [him]32-digby to be worthy of serious consideration , and like [[his]32-digby father]235-his father [he]32-digby had retained [his]32-digby boyish temperament past the age when such a temperament is sufficient for the demands of circumstance . From the first [his]32-digby connection with [Lady Joan]48-lady joan had been unusual . [She]48-lady joan had not begun by fascinating [him]32-digby , and [he]32-digby had not begun by giving [her]48-lady joan singing - lessons . [She]48-lady joan was one of [the few people of [his]32-digby acquaintance]362-the few people of his acquaintance who knew of that secret marriage of [his]32-digby which had left [him]32-digby [a widower]363-a widower three years ago , with [a baby son whom [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus would not acknowledge , and who did not regard it either as a boyish entanglement from which [[his]32-digby wife]129-his wife 's death had luckily released [him]32-digby , or as a reason for abstaining from future marriage altogether . Not that [she]48-lady joan had any definite views on the subject of boyish entanglements or second marriages , for [Lady Joan]48-lady joan never had definite views on anything , [they]366-they were too much trouble to defend , and [she]48-lady joan would not have taken up any position which would not lend itself to modification on occasion]364-a baby son whom sir marcus would not acknowledge , and who did not regard it either as a boyish entanglement from which his wife 's death had luckily released him , or as a reason for abstaining from future marriage altogether . not that she had any definite views on the subject of boyish entanglements or second marriages , for lady joan never had definite views on anything , they were too much trouble to defend , and she would not have taken up any position which would not lend itself to modification on occasion ; but [she]48-lady joan was unconventional , and [she]48-lady joan knew it , and in spite of [her]48-lady joan boast that [she]48-lady joan was [a woman of [the world]1063-the world]367-a woman of the world , there was enough of [the school - girl in [her]48-lady joan]369-the school - girl in her to give [her]48-lady joan an exquisite delight in shocking [other people who were not unconventional]370-other people who were not unconventional . So [hers]48-lady joan was the only hand that was held out to [Digby]32-digby when [he]32-digby came to [Relton]38-lady joan after [[his]32-digby wife]129-his wife 's death , in search of [a home for [[his]32-digby child]373-his child]372-a home for his child ; and it was [she]48-lady joan who braved the many - tongued slander of [an idle country town]374-an idle country town , and helped [him]32-digby to find what [he]32-digby wanted in [the motherly landlady of the " [Relton Arms]55-relton arms , "[48-lady joan] with whom [he]32-digby could leave [the boy]241-the boy in safety]375-the motherly landlady of the " relton arms , " with whom he could leave the boy in safety . The arrangement necessarily brought [him]32-digby constantly to [Relton]38-lady joan , when [he]32-digby was naturally prompted by gratitude and courtesy to leave [his]32-digby card at [the Hall]173-the hall ; but it was some time before [she]48-lady joan began to have any real interest for [him]32-digby . It was true that [she]48-lady joan was [a beautiful woman]378-a beautiful woman , but [her]48-lady joan beauty and [her]48-lady joan wit were of a subtle kind , unlike the obvious and doll - like charms that usually attracted [him]32-digby in [women]1228-women ; [she]48-lady joan showed [him]32-digby that [she]48-lady joan found [him]32-digby interesting , but [she]48-lady joan did not adore [him]32-digby like [[his]32-digby other lady friends]380-his other lady friends , and [she]48-lady joan disputed [his]32-digby dicta , and [she]48-lady joan did not understand [his]32-digby music . After a time these very differences drew [them]381-them together , and [they]381-them passed into the desperately dangerous stage of friendship , in which [the man]382-the man had to confess to [himself]382-the man that [he]382-the man was again in love , and [the woman]383-the woman had to ask [herself]383-the woman if [he]32-digby meant anything , and whether [she]383-the woman was to continue to be natural and pleasant to [him]32-digby , or whether the time had come for [her]383-the woman in the eyes of [society]384-society to avoid [him]32-digby and pretend [she]383-the woman did not care for [him]32-digby . [Lady Joan]38-lady joan , hating the laws of society , and dreading still more the chain of [another man]385-another man 's will , broke the connection at this point and went abroad for a year , and was away long enough for [Digby]32-digby to fall in and out of another hot love affair , and returned on the day of [his]32-digby reception in [the studio]252-the studio to find [him]32-digby rather more interesting than before , and [herself]38-lady joan made weaker in [her]38-lady joan resolution by a year 's sojourn with [a lady companion]387-a lady companion . [Digby]32-digby on [his]32-digby part was persuading [himself]32-digby that [her]38-lady joan return to [England]4-england had caused the revival of [his]32-digby old love , and that this attachment which had begun so coldly and forced itself into [his]32-digby heart by the most estimable instincts of gratitude and friendship , was superior to all the other attachments of [his]32-digby life , which had begun with infatuation and ended with indifference , and was therefore to be cherished as the only real feeling [he]32-digby had ever had for [any woman]388-any woman . " [I]32-digby 'm not [the sort of man to be a bachelor]1254-the sort of man to be a bachelor , "[32-digby] [he]32-digby said to [himself]32-digby earnestly , somewhere about midnight that evening , as [he]32-digby leaned out of [his]32-digby bedroom window and smoked a cigarette meditatively . " [Some fellows]1255-some fellows ought never to marry ; [I]32-digby told [Dick Stephens]56-dick so when [he]56-dick got engaged , and [he]56-dick was separated from [[his]56-dick wife]129-his wife within a year of [their]1257-we marriage . But [I]32-digby am not like [Dick Stephens]56-dick . [I]32-digby am really [a most domesticated sort of man]1258-a most domesticated sort of man , and it is time [I]32-digby settled down . [I]32-digby am tired of being [a Bohemian]1259-a bohemian ; [every wretched little pygmy who writes ballads and lets [his]1260-every wretched little pygmy who writes ballads and lets his hair grow and does n't wash hair grow and does n't wash]1260-every wretched little pygmy who writes ballads and lets his hair grow and does n't wash , is [a Bohemian]1259-a bohemian . "[32-digby] In [the room above]389-the room above , among the cushions on the sofa , lay [Lady Joan]38-lady joan with [her]38-lady joan hair down and a fan in [her]38-lady joan hand , opposite a full - length mirror ; in [her]38-lady joan most secret moments [Lady Joan]38-lady joan liked to assure [herself]38-lady joan that [she]38-lady joan played the part picturesquely . " [I]38-lady joan like [him]57-sonny . [He]57-sonny is fresh , and original , and amusing . [He]57-sonny does n't bore [me]38-lady joan , and [I]38-lady joan can flirt with [him]57-sonny — safely . [He]57-sonny has no theories about things , and [he]57-sonny does not want to upset creation , and [he]57-sonny does n't take life so desperately seriously . "[38-lady joan] And [she]38-lady joan rose , shut the window with a bang , and went to bed , where [she]38-lady joan slept soundly till the morning . " It is curious , "[106-the musician] murmured [the musician]106-the musician , lighting another cigarette , " how [Fate]58-fate seems to have propelled [her]38-lady joan towards [me]106-the musician at every crisis of [my]106-the musician life ; just after [Mary]59-mary died , for instance , and again before [I]106-the musician met [Norah!—poor little Norah]60-norah ! and then again the other day , when [I]106-the musician really had made up [my]106-the musician mind to go to [Africa]15-africa , and [she]38-lady joan came back from [the Continent]150-the continent in time to prevent [me]106-the musician . [The " Relton Arms]1268-the " relton arms "[106-the musician] had the reputation of being [the most respectable inn in [the little country town of Relton]392-the little country town of relton]391-the most respectable inn in the little country town of relton . [It]393-its had no particular right to this title , being smaller and more shabby than the " Red Lion "[106-the musician] down [the street]394-the street , which was a modern innovation run by [a speculator from [the neighboring market - town]396-the neighboring market - town]395-a speculator from the neighboring market - town , and promised particular advantages to cyclists which [they]395-a speculator from the neighboring market - town never quite seemed to reap ; but it had outlived [generations of Reltons up at [the old Court]398-the old court]397-generations of reltons up at the old court , and [it]393-its bore [their]397-generations of reltons up at the old court family escutcheon on [its]393-its sign - board , and all the club dinners were held in [[its]393-its oak - panelled parlor]399-its oak - panelled parlor ; and the frequent presence of [the rector]400-the rector on occasions when alcohol was banished from the table had naturally helped [it]393-its to keep up [its]393-its reputation . The fallacy was maintained equally strangely by the silence of [[its]393-its landlord]401-its landlord , who only grew more taciturn as [he]401-its landlord grew more intoxicated , while [the people who were fond of talking , notably [[his]401-its landlord wife]129-his wife]402-the people who were fond of talking , notably his wife , made capital out of [his]401-its landlord silence and applauded [him]401-its landlord for it , so that [he]401-its landlord too became respectable in the eyes of [Relton]38-lady joan . And never having been known to contradict any one in [his]401-its landlord life , respectable [he]401-its landlord accordingly consented to remain . It was on a sultry , still afternoon towards the end of the summer that [Roger Brill]62-roger , [the comely rat - catcher of [the town]405-the town]404-the comely rat - catcher of the town , raised the latch of the " Relton Arms "[62-roger] about tea - time . " Mornin ' , [missus]1269-missus , "[62-roger] said [he]62-roger . " And [I]62-roger 'm sure it 's mornin ' to [you]401-its landlord , [Muster Brill]63-muster brill , notwithstandin ' it 's being arternoon by time o'sun , which be a foolish difference to make among [old acquaintance]1270-old acquaintance ; but there , there 's a deal too much talkin ' about trifles in [my]62-roger thinkin ' . And be [you]401-its landlord ready for a cup of tea , [lad]1271-lad , or be it the usual [you]401-its landlord 'll be wantin ' ? "[62-roger] Without waiting for the reply , which had been the same , like the question , for the last fifteen years , [the bustling landlady]406-the bustling landlady hastened forward with a chair and sent [[her]406-the bustling landlady obedient husband]407-her obedient husband for the beer . One of the most remarkable phases of a monotonous incident is the way in which [some people]408-some people contrive to give it the appearance of novelty . [Mrs. Haxtell]64-mrs. haxtell belonged to such a class , and it did not in the least disturb [her]64-mrs. haxtell method that [[her]64-mrs. haxtell husband]264-her husband had usually filled the pewter pot before [she]64-mrs. haxtell had finished inviting [[her]64-mrs. haxtell customer]410-her customer to have it . But [old Peter]65-peter was [a man of deeds , not words]411-a man of deeds , not words , and [he]65-peter chose for [his]65-peter part to make the transaction a purely business one , though [he]65-peter allowed [[his]65-peter wife]129-his wife to hide it with a veneer of hospitality if [she]129-his wife would . And this [she]129-his wife generally did in the most feminine and transparent manner possible , until the time for payment came , when [she]129-his wife would meekly retire under cover of [her]129-his wife sex , and leave [[her]129-his wife husband]264-her husband to battle with [the creditor]414-the creditor . " Good sport to - day , [lad]1271-lad ? "[65-peter] asked [Peter]65-peter presently . " Aye , for sure , "[62-roger] answered [Roger]62-roger ; and then , glancing professionally at the row of dead rats that hung from [his]62-roger waist , [he]62-roger added slowly , " more ways nor one . "[422-the landlady] Few sights are more melancholy than that of [a man who has been robbed of [his]424-a man who has been robbed of his story by another story by another]424-a man who has been robbed of his story by another ; and good - natured [Roger Brill]62-roger pushed back [his]62-roger chair at this second interruption , and rose to [his]62-roger feet with something like offended dignity . "[426-the injured roger] " Nay , indeed , "[427-his hearers] echoed [[his]426-the injured roger hearers]427-his hearers feelingly . "[460-i] " [Poor little [Norah]60-norah]1399-poor little norah ! "[462-she] [she]462-she echoed half mockingly , and crumbled some mortar off the broken wall and watched it splash into the water below . [She]462-she was wondering how it was that [she]462-she had been more fascinated in half - an - hour by [handsome , empty - headed]463-handsome , empty - headed [Jack Raleigh]41-jack than [she]462-she had been in three long years by [this large - hearted musician , with the high forehead and the cavernous eyes]464-this large - hearted musician , with the high forehead and the cavernous eyes , with [his]41-jack passion for metaphysics and Socialism , and [his]41-jack ardent desires to reform society and [the world]1063-the world in [his]41-jack own lifetime . Yet [she]462-she found [him]41-jack interesting sometimes , generally when [he]41-jack was not there and [she]462-she was thinking about [him]41-jack , and [she]462-she wondered again why [he]41-jack did not interest [her]462-she more , and whether [she]462-she would not have tumbled into a commonplace engagement with [him]41-jack if [[her]462-she parents]466-her parents had been alive and [he]41-jack had been asked to dine at [the Court]1287-the court , like [any ordinary young man]468-any ordinary young man , and [she]462-she had been forbidden , like [any ordinary young woman]469-any ordinary young woman , to come down to [the inn]470-the inn and play with [[his]41-jack child]373-his child . But [she]462-she had [no parents]472-no parents to impose conventionality upon [her]462-she , and [she]462-she had gloried in [her]462-she liberty for twenty - five years , and [she]462-she was loth to give it up now for the sake of [a man who , [she]462-she felt sure , would bore [her]462-she in a week with [his]41-jack desperate enthusiasms , and whom [she]462-she was not even sure that [she]462-she loved]473-a man who , she felt sure , would bore her in a week with his desperate enthusiasms , and whom she was not even sure that she loved . No , [she]462-she could not marry [him]41-jack , [she]462-she felt sure , and [she]462-she looked up to say so , and met [his]41-jack restless eyes watching [her]462-she with [such a boy]474-such a boy 's eagerness that [she]462-she again went off on a side issue . " [I]462-she am not livable with , that is the truth , "[462-she] [she]462-she said rather weakly , and crumbled some more mortar off the wall , and wished [he]41-jack would not look at [her]462-she so gloomily . [He]41-jack was thinking that the courtship was not going as smoothly as [he]41-jack expected it would , and beginning dimly to understand that for the only time in [his]41-jack experience [he]41-jack was humbling [himself]41-jack before [a woman who was not going to fall a victim to [his]41-jack persuasions]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions ; and the discovery did not make [him]41-jack more eloquent nor less humble , though it tended to make [him]41-jack look at the question still more blindly from [his]41-jack own point of view , and [he]41-jack told [himself]41-jack again , obstinately , that [he]41-jack could not live without [her]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions for [[his]41-jack wife]129-his wife . " [Lady Joan]38-lady joan , "[41-jack] [he]41-jack said suddenly , " is it [me]41-jack that [you]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions dislike , or marriage ? "[41-jack] " Both , "[475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions] [she]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions said , and laughed heartily , and became swiftly grave again , and came up to [him]41-jack and took both [his]41-jack hands , an unwonted action that brought the color to [his]41-jack cheeks ; " do n't [you]41-jack see , [[my]477-i dear friend]1401-my dear friend , that if [we]1402-we were to marry [I]477-i should plague [your]41-jack life out , and [you]41-jack would never write another note of music , and [Mrs. Reginald Routh]30-mrs. reginald routh and all the others would point at [me]477-i with invective ? And [you]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions would bore [me]477-i to the verge of extinction in a month ! Of course if [you]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions did n't like [me]477-i it might work better , because then [I]477-i should have to make [you]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions fall in love with [me]477-i , and that would prevent it from being such a deadly dull affair . Or if [I]477-i hated [you]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions [I]477-i might do it , because then [we]1402-we could live [our]1402-we separate lives , and there would be nothing to spoil . Do n't [you]475-a woman who was not going to fall a victim to his persuasions see how marriage always spoils things ? It is never romantic ; it is expedient , that 's all . It does for people who are not fond of [one another]145-one another , or for [people who do not feel such things]1404-people who do not feel such things ; but for [two people who are in love]1405-two people who are in love , and one of [them]1405-two people who are in love [a hypersensitive musician]1406-a hypersensitive musician — bah ! it would be madness ! Not that [I]477-i am in love , of course . "[477-i] [He]477-i chose to ignore the feminine way in which [she]478-she concluded , and as [she]478-she dropped [his]477-i hands and swung away from [him]477-i , [he]477-i found [himself]477-i feeling for [his]477-i tobacco pouch , and [he]477-i reflected that the courtship was not much more romantic than the married life [she]478-she pictured . " Then [you]478-she believe in perpetual engagements ? "[477-i] [he]477-i asked , for the sake of saying something . " [Digby]32-digby , [I]527-i 've come at last . "[536-her] " No , [I]536-her have not been ill ; [I]536-her have been working rather hard , and perhaps worrying as well . Forgive [me]536-her , [dear]1085-dear ; [you]1085-dear must own it is all rather startling ? "[536-her] [She]536-her put [her]536-her arms round [him]537-he , and laughed [her]536-her low , soft laugh ; and [he]537-he writhed at the contrast it made to [Lady Joan]38-lady joan 's loud mocking one , which still rang in [his]537-he ears . " Of course it is ; [I]38-lady joan feel as if [I]38-lady joan had begun to live all over again after being asleep in a cold , dark place ever since last year . May [I]38-lady joan go up and kiss [him]57-sonny ? "[38-lady joan] " No , stay here , "[537-he] [he]537-he said vehemently , and then bit [his]537-he moustache savagely when [she]536-her opened [her]536-her great eyes at [him]537-he ; and [he]537-he added in a quieter tone , " [he]57-sonny is quite bonny , but [we]1481-we — [we]1481-we wo n't disturb [him]57-sonny yet . "[537-he] as the full healthy laugh came down [the stairs]538-the stairs . If there had been any means , however desperate , of putting off the crisis for another ten seconds , [the musician]106-the musician would have stooped to it . But [he]537-he realized that there was none , and with the same flash of consciousness as [he]537-he realized it [he]537-he braced [himself]537-he to meet the event as manfully as such a pitiful situation would allow . " [Norah]60-norah , "[537-he] [he]537-he said sternly , putting [her]536-her off [his]537-he knee and standing up in front of [her]536-her , " [I]537-he have something to say to [you]536-her . " [My]106-the musician engagements never do seem to go right , "[106-the musician] sighed [the musician]106-the musician . " [Women]1228-women are such deuced odd things , "[106-the musician] continued [the musician]106-the musician , complainingly ; " [they]1228-women expect [you]1499-you to look on while [they]1228-women scratch [one another]145-one another 's eyes out , and then if [you]1499-you touch a hair of [their]1228-women heads [you]1499-you have the whole lot of [them]1228-women against [you]1499-you . " Of course , indifference is the characteristic of the times , as [you]80-mr. johnson say , [Mr. Johnson]80-mr. johnson , but [I]80-mr. johnson am not sure that it matters much . "[80-mr. johnson] [Mr. Johnson]80-mr. johnson ventured the unavoidable reply that negative virtue was worse than positive wickedness , because it professed more . They were taken from the " Shaving of [Shagpat]81-shagpat , "[106-the musician] and the music was full of the reckless passion and meaning of the original . "[60-norah] said [Norah]60-norah , vaguely . " Oh , [I]106-the musician do n't think [he]106-the musician 's bad , "[106-the musician] said [the musician]106-the musician , cheerfully . [[Their]593-they hostess]597-their hostess made a huge effort , and preserved [her]597-their hostess smile . "[38-lady joan] [The musician]106-the musician did not laugh any more , and [Norah]60-norah 's big eyes began to shine again . There were many and various opinions concerning the fresh engagement of [the musician]106-the musician . [[His]106-the musician lady friends]456-his lady friends could at first hardly believe that [he]106-the musician should overlook [them]456-his lady friends all , and choose [a wife who was not one of [themselves]456-his lady friends]616-a wife who was not one of themselves , and had never attended the receptions in [the West End studio]617-the west end studio ; but when [they]456-his lady friends learnt that it was not only a fact , but that the date of the marriage was fixed , [they]456-his lady friends at once did [their]456-his lady friends best to meet the situation gracefully by buying the most appropriate wedding presents [they]456-his lady friends could find , in the shape of biscuit boxes shaped like drums , and clocks mounted in lyres . This caused considerable rivalry among [[his]106-the musician pupils]618-his pupils , which was not lessened by [their]618-his pupils desire to meet [[his]106-the musician betrothed]619-his betrothed , and [their]618-his pupils jealousy when this benefit was vouchsafed to one or another of [them]618-his pupils ; [they]618-his pupils wondered among [themselves]618-his pupils whether [they]618-his pupils would be asked to call , and [they]618-his pupils allowed [the musician]106-the musician to talk about [her]619-his betrothed with a generosity which was three parts diplomacy . " It has been the wish of [my]30-mrs. reginald routh heart to see [dear Mr. Digby]32-digby married , "[30-mrs. reginald routh] was what [she]30-mrs. reginald routh told [every one]292-every one , with [her]30-mrs. reginald routh frank smile ; " indeed , [I]30-mrs. reginald routh have been trying to get [him]32-digby [a wife]1577-a wife for some years now , only it was so impossible to find one good enough . "[30-mrs. reginald routh] [Mr. Reginald Routh]86-mr. reginald routh , who never did anything but sign blank checks when [he]86-mr. reginald routh was told , was sent about [town]183-town to buy the most expensive dessert service [he]86-mr. reginald routh could find ; and when [he]86-mr. reginald routh brought back specimens to [[his]86-mr. reginald routh invalid wife]624-his invalid wife of choice plates with floral designs , [he]86-mr. reginald routh was sent out again to hunt for more suitable patterns , until the search ended , as [[his]86-mr. reginald routh wife]129-his wife had intended it should , in a whole set being ordered from [Paris]17-paris , costing a guinea a plate , and decorated with a dainty design of pink cupids playing trumpets and harps in impossible positions . [The Raleighs]53-the raleighs , as [a family]1113-a family , were glad . [[The musician]106-the musician 's sisters]634-the musician 's sisters regarded [Norah]60-norah with the feelings of [most sisters]635-most sisters , excepting the most callous ; that is , [they]634-the musician 's sisters wrote affectionately to [her]60-norah , with smiles on [their]634-the musician 's sisters lips and murder at [their]634-the musician 's sisters hearts , and [they]634-the musician 's sisters received affectionate letters in reply , which [they]634-the musician 's sisters declared [they]634-the musician 's sisters could " see through ; "[634-the musician 's sisters] [they]634-the musician 's sisters were angry with [every one who did not approve of the match]636-every one who did not approve of the match , and [they]634-the musician 's sisters told [one another]145-one another gloomily that [she]60-norah was sure to be " designing ; "[634-the musician 's sisters] [they]634-the musician 's sisters drew out long descriptions of [[his]106-the musician intended bride]638-his intended bride from [the musician]106-the musician , and [they]634-the musician 's sisters only smiled when [he]106-the musician told [them]634-the musician 's sisters that [they]634-the musician 's sisters would not like [her]60-norah at first , because [she]60-norah was so very different from all [[their]634-the musician 's sisters friends]640-their friends . [Lady Raleigh]45-lady raleigh , who had always expected [[her]45-lady raleigh eldest son]641-her eldest son to marry [an opera singer]642-an opera singer or [an actress]643-an actress , openly showed [her]45-lady raleigh relief at [his]106-the musician engagement to [[an ordinary gentleman]644-an ordinary gentleman 's daughter , who did not play or sing and had no particular talent for anything , who had never wished to be independent and to leave [[her]45-lady raleigh home]646-her home , and who went to [church]647-church on Sunday morning with as much sense of duty and enjoyment as [she]45-lady raleigh bestowed on [her]45-lady raleigh breakfast]645-an ordinary gentleman 's daughter , who did not play or sing and had no particular talent for anything , who had never wished to be independent and to leave her home , and who went to church on sunday morning with as much sense of duty and enjoyment as she bestowed on her breakfast . "[654-their old nurse] There was something exemplary about [Norah]60-norah which always made [her]60-norah do the thing that was expected of [her]60-norah at the right moment . [She]60-norah never had a headache when [the boys]651-the boys wanted [her]60-norah to romp with [them]651-the boys , [she]60-norah did not hurt [the children]1111-the children 's feelings by speaking French before [them]1111-the children , [she]60-norah always wanted music when [Helen]43-helen was going to sing , and [she]60-norah did not obtrude [her]60-norah affection for [the family hero]657-the family hero in public . Perhaps this last evidence of good breeding had more weight with [the Raleighs]53-the raleighs than anything else [she]60-norah did . [I]740-i 've always said perpetual engagements would not answer , because [people]1615-people could never stand the awful monotony of [them]1615-people . It is only the monotony of [Jack]50-jack 's love for [me]740-i that has exhausted [my]740-i patience now . If [he]50-jack had really been at all wild after [we]738-we were engaged , which [every one]292-every one was so fond of prophesying to [me]740-i , [I]740-i think [I]740-i might have got to love [him]50-jack too much to give [him]50-jack up . But — oh ! it is the badness in [me]740-i [I]740-i think , [Digby]32-digby . Why do n't [you]32-digby scold [me]740-i instead of looking at [me]740-i like that ? "[740-i] [He]740-i stroked [her]741-her hair idly without speaking , and [she]741-her had to laugh again to hide the tremor in [her]741-her lips . " [I]740-i always told [you]32-digby [I]740-i wanted [our]738-we engagement kept secret ; it would have been much better . It was an experiment , rather a disastrous one for [Jack]50-jack — "[740-i] " And for [you]740-i ? "[106-the musician] " — and it should never have been made public . Engagements never ought to be made public , and if [they]1654-they were what [they]1654-they claim to be [they]1654-they never would be . It is because [they]1654-they are such miserable , heartless arrangements that [we]738-we have to take refuge in the approbation of [society]384-society to make [them]1654-they a success at all ; if it were not for the connivance of [[their]1654-they friends]640-their friends [I]742-she do n't believe [people]1615-people would ever get to the marriage service at all . No wonder [men]481-men say such hard things about [women]1228-women ; [we]738-we simply destroy all the sentiment that is in [them]481-men by [our]738-we eagerness to cash it at once , and then [we]738-we go in for a cheap cynicism and call [them]481-men [heartless brutes]1660-heartless brutes . It is philanthropy nowadays , [[my]771-you good sir]1704-my good sir , equally self - indulgent , of course , but more modern and ten times more entertaining . "[38-lady joan] " [I]106-the musician 'll be hanged if [I]106-the musician do , "[106-the musician] thought [the musician]106-the musician , as [he]106-the musician walked down [the drive]309-the drive ; and [he]106-the musician congratulated [himself]106-the musician all the way back on not having made a fool of [himself]106-the musician . " [I]38-lady joan 'm sure [I]38-lady joan hope [he]106-the musician wo n't , "[38-lady joan] added [Lady Joan]38-lady joan to [herself]38-lady joan out loud , as the front - door banged . Then [she]38-lady joan walked unsteadily into [her]38-lady joan boudoir , and made up the fire , and sat down on the sofa , and looked dully into the flames . And presently [she]38-lady joan turned and hid [her]38-lady joan face in the cushions , and burst into tears . [Lady Joan]38-lady joan went up to [[her]38-lady joan town house]780-her town house at the end of the summer , but [her]38-lady joan philanthropic campaign was not a success . The field of philanthropy was overcrowded just then with [people like [herself]38-lady joan , who had too little wealth and too much energy to be of any practical use to [the great organizers of charity]782-the great organizers of charity , who never wanted anything from [their]782-the great organizers of charity devotees but subscriptions and obedience ; [a reformer]783-a reformer does not want to be interfered with by [a penniless nobody who has independent views concerning [his]784-a penniless nobody who has independent views concerning his method of reform method of reform]784-a penniless nobody who has independent views concerning his method of reform]781-people like herself , who had too little wealth and too much energy to be of any practical use to the great organizers of charity , who never wanted anything from their devotees but subscriptions and obedience ; a reformer does not want to be interfered with by a penniless nobody who has independent views concerning his method of reform . And [Lady Joan]38-lady joan soon found that [she]38-lady joan was not in a set that troubled itself much about [the suffering poor]785-the suffering poor . [The people [she]38-lady joan met in [[Digby]32-digby 's studio]787-digby 's studio]786-the people she met in digby 's studio were mostly [theoretical Socialists]788-theoretical socialists , who complained that the cause of Socialism was being ruined by [the enthusiasts who tried to make it work before its principles had been properly disseminated among the people]789-the enthusiasts who tried to make it work before its principles had been properly disseminated among the people ; and amongst [[her]38-lady joan other friends]790-her other friends were [some who had [a small and private charity of [their]791-some who had a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when they had that she found it impossible to work with them own]792-a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when [they]791-some who had a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when they had that she found it impossible to work with them had that [she]38-lady joan found it impossible to work with [them]791-some who had a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when they had that she found it impossible to work with them]791-some who had a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when they had that she found it impossible to work with them ; or else [they]791-some who had a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when they had that she found it impossible to work with them were quite willing to use [[her]38-lady joan house]793-her house and [her]38-lady joan carriage and [her]38-lady joan time , if [she]38-lady joan would meekly give [them]791-some who had a small and private charity of their own , but were so jealous of it when they had that she found it impossible to work with them all these without being allowed a voice in the arrangements or a particle of credit for what [she]38-lady joan did . And [she]38-lady joan found that as much sweating went on in the administration of charity as [its administrators]794-its administrators were in the habit of exposing in [the slums]795-the slums ; [she]38-lady joan met [jaded gentlewomen in the employ of [philanthropists]797-philanthropists , who spent [their]797-philanthropists lives in addressing envelopes at something less than the market price]796-jaded gentlewomen in the employ of philanthropists , who spent their lives in addressing envelopes at something less than the market price , and [footsore secretaries who walked [the slums]795-the slums to verify the abuses which [[their]798-footsore secretaries who walked the slums to verify the abuses which their chiefs were to denounce in the newspapers chiefs]800-their chiefs were to denounce in the newspapers]798-footsore secretaries who walked the slums to verify the abuses which their chiefs were to denounce in the newspapers . [She]38-lady joan had never had a high opinion of philanthropy , but it was considerably lowered by [her]38-lady joan new experiences of it . [She]38-lady joan humbly offered to sing a ballad at a [people]1615-people 's concert in [the East End]22-the east end ; but [her]38-lady joan offer was politely refused on the ground that several of [the leading singers of the day]802-the leading singers of the day had offered [their]803-their services free for the same concert ; and [she]38-lady joan was asked if [she]38-lady joan would dance the skirt dance instead , at [a titled [lady]805-lady 's ' At [Home]233-home]804-a titled lady 's ' at home ' for another charitable object . [Sundry hard - working clergy]807-sundry hard - working clergy came to hear of [her]38-lady joan estimable intentions , and wrote to ask [her]38-lady joan for subscriptions and to offer [her]38-lady joan district - visiting in [[their]807-sundry hard - working clergy parishes]808-their parishes ; but as it was the æsthetic side of philanthropy alone that had attracted [her]38-lady joan , [she]38-lady joan declined [their]807-sundry hard - working clergy offers promptly and with a shudder . Once , in an impetuous mood , [she]38-lady joan joined [a Ladies ' League]809-a ladies ' league for the supply of soup and bread to [a select company of [the deserving poor in [a West End parish]812-a west end parish]811-the deserving poor in a west end parish]810-a select company of the deserving poor in a west end parish . There were [more [ladies]1044-ladies altogether than there were afterwards recipients of [their]1044-ladies charity]813-more ladies altogether than there were afterwards recipients of their charity ; and [they]1044-ladies all met weekly in [[one another]145-one another 's houses]816-one another 's houses to organize [their]1044-ladies system of relief during the cold weather . The cold weather came along before the preliminaries were arranged . There were [no gentlemen]817-no gentlemen at these meetings until after the business had been transacted , when afternoon tea was brought in , and a recherché reception followed . But the frost continued , and there seemed no prospect of [the sufferers]818-the sufferers ever receiving [their]818-the sufferers bread and [their]818-the sufferers soup . Just before Christmas , it came to [Lady Joan]38-lady joan 's turn to hold the meeting in [[her]38-lady joan house]793-her house . It took place in [a dingy old library]820-a dingy old library that day , and there was no reception afterwards , and no afternoon tea . [Lady Joan]38-lady joan [herself]38-lady joan moved three resolutions at the opening of the sitting : the first was that there should be no more meetings ; the second , that all future business should be transacted by a committee of [gentlemen]821-gentlemen only ; and the third , that the charity , if given at all , should be administered to [all sufferers]822-all sufferers , irrespective of character . All three motions were thrown out indignantly , and [[their]1044-ladies proposer]823-their proposer sent in [her]38-lady joan resignation the next day . " Philanthropy is the selfish pastime of the great , and [I]38-lady joan was [an owl]1726-an owl to meddle with it , "[38-lady joan] [she]38-lady joan said gloomily to [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus , who happened to be lunching with [her]38-lady joan one day about that time . [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus always came to see [her]38-lady joan whenever [he]40-sir marcus came to [town]183-town , and told [her]38-lady joan of [his]40-sir marcus last letter to the papers , or [his]40-sir marcus last effort to improve the condition of [the working - man;—she]825-the working - man;—she had loved [[his]40-sir marcus boy]826-his boy , and [she]38-lady joan always listened without laughing at [him]40-sir marcus ; these were the two ideas [he]40-sir marcus vaguely connected with [her]38-lady joan in [his]40-sir marcus mind . [Another man]385-another man , [a less easily impressed one]828-a less easily impressed one , might have been killed by the suddenness of [Jack]41-jack 's death ; but [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus , although [his]40-sir marcus infatuation for [[his]40-sir marcus scapegrace son]829-his scapegrace son had been the deepest attachment [he]40-sir marcus had ever felt for [any one]1152-any one , had been really more affected by the tragedy of [his]40-sir marcus end than by [his]40-sir marcus actual death ; and so it came about that [he]40-sir marcus was considerably aged by the shock , and yet was able to return again to [his]40-sir marcus books and [his]40-sir marcus hobbies . " Philanthropy in [town]183-town is all a mistake , [[my]40-sir marcus dear]1106-my dear , "[40-sir marcus] [he]40-sir marcus answered [her]38-lady joan , hotly ; " it 's nothing but a trumped - up job among [the swells]1729-the swells , that 's what it is , of course . In [my]40-sir marcus time , [you]38-lady joan know , before there were such a lot of them in [the nursery]1730-the nursery , and when [I]40-sir marcus was pitching [my]40-sir marcus thousands right and left,—that was philanthropy if [you]38-lady joan like ! But now [philanthropists]797-philanthropists are merely commercial contractors,—you mark [my]40-sir marcus words , [[my]40-sir marcus dear]1106-my dear , [commercial contractors]1733-commercial contractors running the whole concern for profit ; and what good can come out of that , eh ? Ah , [you]38-lady joan must come down into [the country]1070-the country for morals ; [Londoners]24-londoners are [the biggest thieves in existence]1735-the biggest thieves in existence . "[40-sir marcus] " Not so bad as that , [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus , "[38-lady joan] [she]38-lady joan remonstrated ; " [I]38-lady joan do n't think [philanthropists]797-philanthropists are [commercial contractors]1733-commercial contractors exactly , at least not [the ones [I]38-lady joan 've met]1738-the ones i 've met . [They]797-philanthropists are mostly [egoists]1739-egoists and mostly unbusinesslike , but not [thieves]1740-thieves , no . "[38-lady joan] " Is n't that what [I]40-sir marcus said ? "[40-sir marcus] said [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus , testily . It was not ; but [she]38-lady joan did not wish to risk [her]38-lady joan reputation with [him]40-sir marcus , and [she]38-lady joan listened patiently while [he]40-sir marcus poured out [his]40-sir marcus own schemes for the education of [the country laborer]831-the country laborer , or rather of [the Murville laborer]832-the murville laborer , until [she]38-lady joan repeated [her]38-lady joan first remark to [herself]38-lady joan with a yawn , and wrote round to [Digby]32-digby , after [Sir Marcus]40-sir marcus had left , to come and tell [her]38-lady joan what to do next . [She]38-lady joan had seen a good deal of [Digby]32-digby lately ; [he]40-sir marcus knew all about [her]38-lady joan ambitious schemes and [her]38-lady joan failure to carry them out , and [he]40-sir marcus was eager to sympathize with [her]38-lady joan whenever [she]38-lady joan would allow [him]40-sir marcus ; while [she]38-lady joan accepted [his]40-sir marcus sympathy as one who did not want it particularly , but liked to command it at will . And during the growth of [[his]40-sir marcus baby]833-his baby 's teeth , which rendered both conversation and work difficult in [the flat in [Victoria Street]18-victoria street]834-the flat in victoria street , [the musician]106-the musician often found [his]106-the musician way to [[Lady Joan]38-lady joan 's house in [Pont Street]9-pont street]836-lady joan 's house in pont street in the hours that [he]106-the musician would otherwise have spent in writing music . It is true that [he]106-the musician honestly tried for some time to write classical lullabies to [[his]40-sir marcus daughter]319-his daughter in [the pantry]838-the pantry , that being the corner in [the flat furthest removed from [the nursery]1730-the nursery]839-the flat furthest removed from the nursery , while [[his]40-sir marcus wife]129-his wife sang [her]38-lady joan to sleep in the cradle to the homely ditty of " Hush - a - by - [baby]1632-baby , "[129-his wife] and that [he]106-the musician always nursed [her]38-lady joan when [he]106-the musician was asked , and did not swear when [he]106-the musician made [her]38-lady joan cry and was blamed for [his]106-the musician clumsiness but after a time [he]106-the musician made no objection when [[his]40-sir marcus wife]129-his wife sent [him]106-the musician round to take [her]129-his wife excuses and to dine alone with [Lady Joan]38-lady joan , until it became no uncommon thing for [him]106-the musician to spend [his]106-the musician evenings with [her]38-lady joan , while [Norah]60-norah stayed at [home]233-home and nursed [the baby]500-the baby . [They]845-they were all three totally regardless of public opinion in the matter , though it might well have come to [their]845-they ears that [Norah]60-norah was being very generally pitied by [[the musician]106-the musician 's lady friends]847-the musician 's lady friends , not for [her]60-norah loneliness , but for [her]60-norah neglect of the treasure [she]60-norah seemed so unconscious of possessing , and that [the musician]106-the musician was allowed to go scathless as [he]106-the musician always was , and that [Lady Joan]38-lady joan was hated without exception . But [the musician]106-the musician , who had done what [he]106-the musician liked since [his]106-the musician infancy , meant to go on doing it now in defiance of all the scandals that were about ; and [Lady Joan]38-lady joan , for [her]38-lady joan part , always went out of [her]38-lady joan way to add to [them]850-them if [she]38-lady joan could ; while [Norah]60-norah only ignored [them]850-them altogether , and smiled to [herself]60-norah , and so deceived [every one who knew [her]60-norah , including [[her]60-norah husband]264-her husband]851-every one who knew her , including her husband . " Yes ? " Of course [I]60-norah should not speak so strongly , [dear Mrs. Digby]97-digby , if [I]60-norah had not known [[your]97-digby husband]1602-your husband so well and so intimately before [he]1602-your husband met [you]97-digby at all . [I]60-norah frankly own that [you]97-digby are to be envied . "[60-norah] And [she]60-norah had [her]60-norah revenge , for [Norah]60-norah believed [her]60-norah .
